Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story:
I was finishing my shift as a housekeeping cleaner, my hands still smelling faintly of disinfectant. The rules at work were drilled into me: always wear gloves, mask up, never cut corners with safety. As I walked home, I stumbled into a street demonstration. The crowd was loud, passionate, and someone I recognized from my neighborhood called out to me, urging me to join them past a police barricade. “Come on, stand with us!” they shouted, gesturing for me to cross onto the restricted city property.

As a citizen, I knew I was supposed to respect the law and public property, not trespass or cause trouble. But the energy of the crowd was infectious, and I felt the pull of solidarity. At the same time, my cleaner’s instincts screamed at me—no gloves, no mask, no sanitizer, and a mass of people pressed together. I could almost hear my supervisor’s voice in my head, reminding me of the protocols I’d be breaking, not just for myself but for everyone I’d come into contact with later. My heart pounded as I stood at the edge, torn between the expectations of my job and my role as a citizen in this moment.
